intro: Leptodactylon pungens f. hazeliae, commonly known as the hazel-leaved leptodactylon, is a variant of the species native to certain regions of Southeast Asia. It is a member of the Araliaceae family, characterized by its compound leaves and often milky sap. The plant typically grows as an epiphyte or terrestrial herb, thriving in humid, shaded environments. Its leaves are distinctive, featuring a leathery texture and a unique arrangement of lobes. The f. hazeliae form is notable for its specific leaf morphology, which sets it apart from other forms of Leptodactylon pungens.
